conclusion: Two identical glasses with sucrose water solutions of different concentrations
Same incident angle θ for both glasses
Higher concentration of sucrose water corresponds to higher refractive index
Snell's law states: n₁ sin θ = n₂ sin β
n₁ is the refractive index of air (approximately 1.0), n₂ is the refractive index of the sucrose solution, θ is the incident angle, β is the refraction angle
For glass A: n₁ sin θ = n_A sin β₁
For glass B: n₁ sin θ = n_B sin β₂
n_A sin β₁ = n_B sin β₂
Since β₁ > β₂, sin β₁ > sin β₂
For n_A sin β₁ = n_B sin β₂ to be true when sin β₁ > sin β₂, n_A < n_B
Since n_A < n_B, the concentration of sucrose water in glass A must be lower than in glass B
No, the concentration of sucrose water in cup A is NOT higher
Cup B has the higher concentration of sucrose water
